results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film is a wonderful composite of the Nixon family’s life enjoying the company of their extended family at weddings, birthday gatherings and at the family holiday homes as well as on their travels to the Gold Coast, Queensland and Eildon Weir, Victoria. We see Karen turn six in the film as well as a great Christmas scene when both children are particularly excited to receive their presents, a watch for Karen and a scooter for Stuart.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 children on the beach at Portarlington
00:00:52:00 at a zoo
00:02:40:00 wedding with a tall headdress for the bride and bridesmaids in dark pink 1960s style dresses
00:04:10:00 Karen’s first day at school, in her uniform with school bag
00:04:24:00 Stuart on a trike (tricycle) saluting the camera
00:04:40:00 picnic on the beach with lots of extended family members
00:05:00:00 treasure hunt in the sand
00:06:54:00 the children on a farm tractor
00:07:20:00 the cousins of the family in a row at a driveway gate
00:08:19:00 Les, Karen and Stuart walking out of the water at the beach
00:09:49:00 children amusement park on ‘dodgem’ cars
00:11:26:00 Karen and Stuart being rowed in a rowboat, followed by a speedboat rushing past, very close to the shore
00:12:00:00 view of waterfront houses at the Gold Coast
00:12:10:00 TAA airplane taking off at an airport
00:13:27:00 extended family wedding with bridesmaids in what would have been (at the time) a very fashionable and wonderful burnt orange
00:15:28:00 Stuart receiving his Christmas scooter
00:16:00:00 Dorothy and daughter Karen in matching outfits
00:16:25:00 family members gathered under some shady trees at the beach
00:16:47:00 Karen very confidently ‘dinking’ her younger brother Stuart on his new scooter (by giving him a ride)
00:19:27:00 Dorothy and other women in the family laugh as they climb up, and fall on, a steep sand dune
00:20:13:00 Dorothy, Karen and Stuart stand outside their caravan at the beach
00:20:19:00 a family wedding, bridesmaids in purple and sporting some great examples of 1960s hairstyles
00:21:43:00 Karen’s sixth birthday party
00:22:27:00 Karen backstroking through the water
00:23:17:00 family picnic including a woman wearing a wonderful paisley shirt typical of fashion at the time
00:24:40:00 cooking on a vintage three-legged barbeque
00:26:00:00 a birthday party held at a holiday home possibly at Point Roadknight

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

In this film, the Nixon family are living in Alice Springs in 1966, until we see them returning to Victoria via a TAA flight. TAA (Trans Australian Airlines) was the major air service in the 1960s and 1970s flying to destinations all over Australian and its near neighbours of Papua New Guinea and Timor. One of the most memorable advertising jingles at the time was ‘Up, Up and away, with TAA, the Friendly, Friendly Way…’, a variation on the 1967 song Up, Up and Away, written by Jimmy Webb and also used by the US airline TWA.

At home in Herne Hill, new baby Stuart is introduced to the camera, in his ‘bassinette’, laughing at the camera, bouncing in a ‘bouncinette’, in his bath, in his ‘highchair’ and sitting on big sister Karen’s lap. The family spend time at the beach and Karen celebrates her fourth birthday.

Scenes of the Melbourne Zoo show the difference in standards for zoological practices between the 1960s and contemporary practices.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:23:00 view of houses in the arid setting of Alice Springs
00:01:15:00 mountain scenery seen across the scrubby desert
00:01:49:00 memorial for ‘Flynn of the Inland’
00:02:22:00 Dorothy wearing a very 1960s style ‘sunsuit’ for hot weather
00:02:30:00 children playing in a portable backyard swimming pool
00:03:16:00 views of rocks and a creek followed by Alice Springs township from a higher vantage point
00:04:50:00 (faint) carvings on a rock face
00:05:15:00 ‘John Flynn Church’
00:05:25:00 cars in Alice Springs
00:05:56:00 Karen wearing sunglasses
00:06:40:00 views around an Indigenous settlement
00:07:11:00 children eating watermelon
00:07:28:00 floods in the outback
00:07:45:00 TAA (Trans Australian Airlines) airplane on the tarmac at an outback airport
00:07:53:00 propeller of flying plane and views of the sea and land below, followed by landing scenes
00:08:51:00 scenes of baby Stuart at home in Herne Hill, Geelong
00:09:50:00 baby Stuart in a ‘bouncinette’ and in his ‘bassinette’
00:11:55:00 Les and Karen with baby Stuart
00:12:42:00 Dorothy in a Ford ‘Cortina’ model car
00:13:29:00 scenes at the beach
00:14:03:00 Karen and companion buried in the sand at the beach
00:15:48:00 scenes at the Melbourne Zoo
00:16:33:00 Karen’s fourth birthday celebrations
00:17:13:00 baby Stuart almost crawling across the carpet
00:18:08:00 Karen shows a popular activity of the time – the ‘hula hoop’
00:18:45:00 Stuart in a crate on the back of a bicycle
00:18:47:00 Karen shows off her ‘cowgirl’ outfit
00:19:17:00 baby Stuart walking
00:19:31:00 Karen and baby brother Stuart on a tricycle (trike)
00:21:00:00 baby Stuart walking with a toy lawn mower, on his tricycle and with Karen showing off a new outfit
00:21:37:00 at the beach and in the water
00:22:21:00 Dorothy and the children in new outfits in red and orange
00:23:06:00 late 1960s or early 1970s wedding
00:23:28:00 Les in 1970s style shorts and long socks
00:24:04:00 a ‘Victa’ brand lawn mower
00:25:30:00 garden scenes
00:25:40:00 a cricket game

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

Their children having grown up, this film captures Les and Dorothy enjoying a holiday in New Zealand.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Dorothy Nixon and two companions are part of a travel trip as indicated by their name tags
00:00:17:00 sign for ‘trial plots’ as part of a nursery in New Zealand, followed by Dorothy enjoying some views of public gardens
00:01:12:00 sign for ‘Cockayne Memorial Garden’ in honour of Dr Leonard Cockayne, a significant botanist in New Zealand
00:01:31:00 a conservatory in the gardens
00:02:00:00 a large lake amongst hills and a ship, a yacht and boats
00:02:13:00 views toward snowy covered mountains and looking down over a town from a higher vantage point followed by more snowy mountain tops
00:03:07:00 a tourist bus stopped at a roadside lookout point followed by more lakeside scenery
00:03:30:00 filming the mountains and landscape from inside a small plane
00:04:19:00 views of the motel accommodation for the travellers
00:05:10:00 sign for the ‘Omarama Motel Lodge’
00:05:34:00 a peacock, several small deer
00:06:01:00 sign ‘Welcome to Lake Manapouri’
00:06:20:00 a waterfall and tourists on a walk bridge over ‘Falls Creek’
00:06:45:00 filming from a bus as it travels through mountains
00:07:19:00 filming among fellow tourists in a boat on a river taking in the spectacular views of waterfalls and mountains
00:09:42:00 a steam train comes into view on a country track followed by views of houses and trees across a lake
00:10:18:00 looking at the front of a paddle steamer
00:10:40:00 filming from a sky lift as it travels up a hill followed by views over a town below
00:11:11:00 looking at the sky lift as it travels up
00:11:24:00 tourists walk over a bridge looking down at a fast moving creek or river
00:12:52:00 a helicopter landing
00:13:52:00 views of ‘Shantytown’, a tourist attraction on the South Island
00:14:41:00 on board a tourist boat on a lake
00;15:21:00 sign for ‘New Zealand Electricity’ after views of the plant
00:15:27:00 various ‘Wharenui’ (Maori meeting house) followed by views of hot springs
00:16:16:00 on a light plane travelling over a lake looking down on a seaplane
00:17:12:00 memorial to ‘Michael Joseph Savage 1872 – 1940’
00:17:20:00 traditional Maori dance performance
00:18:04:00 scenes of the rolling waves around the rocky coast
00:18:28:00 the travellers gather at the sign for ‘Tane Mahuta (Lord of the Forest)’, a very tall tree
00:18:30:00 the bus tour passengers, including Len and Dorothy, bid each other farewell, followed by travelling by taxi to the airport and ‘Quantas’ and ‘Air New Zealand’ planes at the terminals

00:00:17:00 sign for ‘trial plots’ as part of a nursery in New Zealand, followed by Dorothy enjoying some views of public gardens
00:01:12:00 sign for ‘Cockayne Memorial Garden’ in honour of Dr Leonard Cockayne, a significant botanist in New Zealand
00:01:31:00 a conservatory in the gardens
00:02:00:00 a large lake amongst hills and a ship, a yacht and boats
00:02:13:00 views toward snowy covered mountains and looking down over a town from a higher vantage point followed by more snowy mountain tops
00:03:07:00 a tourist bus stopped at a roadside lookout point followed by more lakeside scenery
00:03:30:00 filming the mountains and landscape from inside a small plane
00:04:19:00 views of the motel accommodation for the travellers
00:05:10:00 sign for the ‘Omarama Motel Lodge’
00:05:34:00 a peacock, several small deer
00:06:01:00 sign ‘Welcome to Lake Manapouri’
00:06:20:00 a waterfall and tourists on a walk bridge over ‘Falls Creek’
00:06:45:00 filming from a bus as it travels through mountains
00:07:19:00 filming among fellow tourists in a boat on a river taking in the spectacular views of waterfalls and mountains
00:09:42:00 a steam train comes into view on a country track followed by views of houses and trees across a lake
00:10:18:00 looking at the front of a paddle steamer
00:10:40:00 filming from a sky lift as it travels up a hill followed by views over a town below
00:11:11:00 looking at the sky lift as it travels up
00:11:24:00 tourists walk over a bridge looking down at a fast moving creek or river
00:12:52:00 a helicopter landing
00:13:52:00 views of ‘Shantytown’, a tourist attraction on the South Island
00:14:41:00 on board a tourist boat on a lake
00;15:21:00 sign for ‘New Zealand Electricity’ after views of the plant
00:15:27:00 various ‘Wharenui’ (Maori meeting house) followed by views of hot springs
00:16:16:00 on a light plane travelling over a lake looking down on a seaplane
00:17:12:00 memorial to ‘Michael Joseph Savage 1872 – 1940’
00:17:20:00 traditional Maori dance performance
00:18:04:00 scenes of the rolling waves around the rocky coast
00:18:28:00 the travellers gather at the sign for ‘Tane Mahuta (Lord of the Forest)’, a very tall tree
00:18:30:00 the bus tour passengers, including Len and Dorothy, bid each other farewell, followed by travelling by taxi to the airport and ‘Quantas’ and ‘Air New Zealand’ planes at the terminals
description_for_label:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

Their children having grown up, this film captures Les and Dorothy enjoying a holiday in New Zealand.

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

In this film Les and Dorothy Nixon show off their first baby Karen (who features in the Nixon Collection until she is an adult herself) at their home in Herne Hill, Geelong, Victoria. There are also a few family weddings and visits and outings around Victoria.

These scenes are a lovely showcase of a baby’s first months, Karen’s first smiles, sitting up, being fed first ‘solids’, learning to crawl on the carpet, trying to open the kitchen cupboards and eventually walking. As well as these usual baby activities we see them in the context of the 1960s - style of clothes, carseat, bassinette, pram and playpen.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:25:00 infant Karen being carried around the family backyard by teenage girls, (possibly cousins in the large extended Corry-Nixon family)
00:01:02:00 family members climb a rock formation, followed by views of surrounding scenery
00:01:15:00 scenes of baby Karen’s christening or baptism day (assumed by the style of baby clothes and blanket and by Dorothy’s smart outfit which includes matching hat, gloves and necklace)
00:01:37:00 baby Karen being held by her grandmother and great aunt
00:01:47:00 baby Karen with father Len
00:02:19:00 baby Karen laughing in her bassinette
00:02:30:00 a family gathering for a beach picnic
00:04:11:00 extended family members gather for a photo with baby Karen
00:05:45:00 baby Karen being fed from a bowl, while she sits in her bassinette on the back porch of the home followed by a bath
00:06:54:00 a ‘dummy’ (pacifier or soother) hanging from above the bassinette
00:07:11:00 extended family members gather in front of one of their homes for a group scene; one of the women flits across the screen playfully swinging her skirt for the camera
00:08:00:00 baby Karen with Dorothy
00:08:57:00 a Holden model car from the era
00:10:20:00 baby Karen’s new car seat
00:11:21:00 an older baby Karen with a cousin in the backyard
00:12:09:00 a very 1960s style wedding
00:12:12:00 baby Karen chases an empty cigarette pack across the carpet floor, practising her crawling
00:13:57:00 baby Karen in her pram
00:14:46:00 Les mowing the lawn
00:15:08:00 first steps for Karen, with dad
00:15:30:00 at the beach, splashing around in the sea with cousins
00:16:25:00 family members paddle boarding and surfing
00:17:38:00 Karen wearing a sunbonnet in a ‘playpen’
00:18:46:00 Karen playing and laughing with dad
00:19:17:00 a lovely little rowboat named ‘Sea Wyf’
00:20:14:00 Karen crawling and first steps
00:21:40:00 Karen ‘frosting’ the window
00:21:56:00 a family picnic
00:24:01:00 women dressed in smart outfits including hats
00:24:09:00 1960s wedding in light blue
00:25:50:00 toddler Karen playing with bucket and spade at the beach
00:26:25:00 Karen and Les practise swimming with a board and family beach scenes
00:28:18:00 gladioli flowers in a vase, in the fashion of the day
00:30:43:00 public gardens

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The Nixon Family Home Movie Collection tells the story of a suburban family in 1960s–1980s Geelong, Victoria, with Mum (Dorothy) and Dad (Les) and the two kids, Karen and Stuart. Les and Dorothy lived at Herne Hill, Geelong, where the films show the two children growing up. Particularly Karen, from when she was a newborn baby up to her 21st birthday and first car.

Captured over ten movies, initially on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, most of the footage was taken by Les but occasionally when he appears on screen, we know Dorothy was behind the camera.

Through these family films we see the children grow up, the fun of beach holidays, fancy hats worn at family weddings, games played at birthdays and special holiday destinations. Some of the loveliest footage shows the simple pastimes of children: ‘dinking’ your baby brother around in the back of the tricycle at home, burying yourself up to the waist in the sand at the beach and jumping over a sprinkler on a hot day in the backyard by the ‘Hills Hoist’.

The large extended family also feature in the films and they would often holiday at their cousin’s beach house at 8th Avenue, Point Roadknight, on the Surf Coast of Victoria. In 1966, the family also spent some time in the sandy yard of a home in Alice Springs, from where they visit Amoonguna, an indigenous community 15kms southwest of Alice.

Visits from “Nana and Pop”, playing tennis, visiting a farm and family picnics also feature. Forget ‘lifestyles of the rich and famous’, this family collection spanning over twenty one years is far more enlightening and endearing.

This collection of home movies was donated to ACMI by Karen Corry.

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexander’s son Mac.

This reel captures the excitement of the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne with footage of the decorated buildings in the city featuring the department stores of the era – Foy’s, Buckley’s, Myer, Coles Store and Woolworths. Also included is a family wedding and scenes from the beach.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 views of Melbourne’s decorated department stores – Foy’s, Buckley’s, Myer, Coles Store (as it was named then) and Woolworths
00:01:42:00 family wedding scenes
00:02:54:00 wedding shots at the church including 1950s fashion style
00:03:24:00 family members at the beach show off the style of the day – striped towels, and a range of clothes from trousers to bathers with ‘shirring’ and sundresses

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexandar’s son Mac.

This reel features scenes of the family in the countryside, walking, driving and a visit to the ‘Sea Winds Cafe’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:45:00 after views of a large waterway and the countryside, people standing by a 1940s car and a ‘Bonds Greyhound Line’ bus
00:01:33:00 road footage taken from inside the car
00:02:00:00 women and dog wandering along through grassland
00:02:30:00 woman knitting in a deckchair
00:03:05:00 a cafe for which we see a glimpse of the sign before the footage ends, ‘Sea Winds Cafe’

description_for_label:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexandar’s son Mac.

This reel features scenes of the family in the countryside, walking, driving and a visit to the ‘Sea Winds Cafe’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:45:00 after views of a large waterway and the countryside, people standing by a 1940s car and a ‘Bonds Greyhound Line’ bus
00:01:33:00 road footage taken from inside the car
00:02:00:00 women and dog wandering along through grassland
00:02:30:00 woman knitting in a deckchair
00:03:05:00 a cafe for which we see a glimpse of the sign before the footage ends, ‘Sea Winds Cafe’

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexendar’s son Mac.

This reel features the family at Carrum beach in Victoria. We see some great examples of swimsuits at the time as well as women’s suits and hats and a boy in a kilt. The reel ends with scenes around the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 begins with two women and a boy walking through sandy bush to the beach, smiling at the camera
00:00:36:00 father and son atop an upturned boat on the beach, posing and waving for the camera
00:00:35:00 the boy running along the sand toward the camera
00:00:45:00 woman running from a bathing box along the sand, stopping briefly for the camera where we see her wearing a knotted headscarf, typical of the day, as a bathing cap
00:01:30:00 man drying himself post swim
00:01:35:00 example of a halter neck one piece women’s swimwear of the era
00:01:57:00 scenes of bushland before we see people picking blackberries
00:02:40:00 a child stares at the camera
00:02:45:00 two older women wearing suits and felt hats typical of the era, sitting on a car running board, one knitting
00:03:00:00 the family group are playing for the camera before playing in a park
00:03:35:00 group picnic around the cars so the running boards can be used as seats
00:04:40:00 riverside stroll with terrier dog
00:05:07:00 backyard cricket practice
00:06:00:00 young boy in kilt and cap with mother in stylish suit and shoes of the day
00:06:11:00 scenes around the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexendar’s son Mac.

This reel is of the filmmaker’s daughter Jean and her visitor, Toddy. Toddy is in military uniform when he rounds a corner of a house to chat happily to Jean, with their dog and pet birds. While on leave from the RAF, Toddy was billeted to the family home in Essendon during his time in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:01:00 Toddy enters the frame from a side path of to visit Jean at her home
00:00:12:00 Jean leans out the window to chat to Toddy
00:00:16:00 Toddy enthusiastically welcomes a dog into the scene
00:00:20:00 Jean presents two pet birds on her arm for the camera
